source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: In order to grow the grains, several different heat treatments were tried, based on earlier recrystallization work $[ I 2 ]$ . The two finally selected resulted in partial (PSR) and total (TSR) secondary recrystallization (Fig. 1). They included heating the central part of the samples up to $8 4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ for $1 0 \ \mathrm { m i n }$ , then decreasing the temperature to 800 or ${ \bf 8 2 0 ^ { \circ } C } .$ respectively, keeping them at these values for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ followed by furnace cooling. This procedure was conducted under vacuum, giving the following grain structures: ${ ( a ) }$ isolated disk-shaped single crystals a few millimetres in diameter and extending over the wall thickness, surrounded by small (about $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in diameter) grains (PSR structure); and $( b )$ single crystals only (TSR structure).
process_step: heating up to 840°C for 10 min, then decreasing to 800°C or 820°C respectively, keeping for 24 h, furnace cooling

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: Internally pressurized tube-type SCC tests [13] were conducted, with $9 9 . 9 9 \%$ pure argon as inert gas; in all but a few control cases, one gram of bisublimated iodine was added, giving a concentration well above the SCC threshold values. The working temperature was $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: After that the samples were rinsed in boiling tridistilled water according to the recommendations contained in the ASTM Practice for Aqueous Corrosion Testing of Samples of Zirconium and Zirconium Alloys (G 2-74), the rest followed the normal procedure described for the majority of the samples.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk2
evidence_span: Typical SCC evidence was found in the tests conducted with iodine: considerable loss of ductility, stress to failure lower than measured in an inert environment, and cleavage-like transgranular cracking.

evidence_span: As it can be seen in all cases, the agreement is excellent, with differences less than $1 ^ { \circ }$ indicating that SCC transgranular propagation by pseudo-cleavage occurs only along basal planes.

evidence_span: In Sample 1, where two fissures were found, Grain 1 (the most highly stressed) cracked first before Grain 4, the second most highly stressed. In this sample, Grain 5, having the maximum resolved shear stress parallel to basal planes, has not cracked.

evidence_span: A crack in a crystal that had been deformed prior to the test (Fig. 7) follows a path that changes directions while propagating transgranularly along different crystal planes.

evidence_span: in a sample showing many deformation features, it is clear that the fissure leaves the basal plane only to follow the angle of twin boundaries.

evidence_span: The corresponding fracture surface is shown in the stereo pair of Fig. 8, in which the common cleavage-like facets can be seen on the basal planes.

evidence_span: the most interesting feature (seen in Fig. 10) is the propagation along a twin boundary (not fractographically identified before) consisting of a flat surface with very few details and no river patterns or steps.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: Single crystals grown in Zircaloy-4 tubes have been cracked in an environment containing iodine.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: SCC transgranular fissures propagate along basal planes, only in those grains having the maximum tensile stress resolved perpendicular to them.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk4

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Transgranular pseudo-cleavage of zirconium alloys produced during iodine SCC occurs along basal planes.

evidence_span: A triaxial stress state seems to be necessary for the process to start and continue.

evidence_span: The results support a decohesion model in which mechanical, chemical, and thermal energies combine to exceed the binding energy of the zirconium atoms.

evidence_span: the energy distribution statistics will perhaps make it impossible to find a threshold stress value for SCC

evidence_span: For samples tested in iodine, it is usually found that the crack starts as intergranular and later grows as transgranular with pseudo-cleavage.

evidence_span: For samples tested in iodine, it is usually found that the crack starts as intergranular and later grows as transgranular with pseudo-cleavage.

evidence_span: Intergranular SCC initiation has often been seen in the polycrystalline part of tubes with a mixed structure (grains grown as large wall-to-wall single crystals surrounded by a microstructure composed by grains of about 20 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ diameter).

evidence_span: grains of about 20 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ diameter

evidence_span: transgranular cracks in our single crystals do not start at grain boundaries. On the contrary, all the through-wall cracks have initiated and propagated transgranularly in those macrograins

evidence_span: transgranular cracks in our single crystals do not start at grain boundaries. On the contrary, all the through-wall cracks have initiated and propagated transgranularly in those macrograins

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Iodine SCC of Zircaloy may not be considered a typical electrochemical process by anodic dissolution since the aggressive environment is not a polar solvent and there is no charge transference through a metal-electrolite interface.
value: not typical electrochemical process by anodic dissolution

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Reduction of zirconium-zirconium bonds by adsorption of corrodant species at the crack tip is an accepted mechanism for liquid metal embrittlement; it is considered that it may apply for the SCC case too
value: reduction of zirconium-zirconium bonds by adsorption

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: A recently proposed surface mobility based SCC mechanism (Ref 15 of this paper) that serves to explain other types of environmental-assisted cracking as well allows for a better understanding of the kinetics of the process.

evidence_span: In Zircaloy-4 with short annealing times and high post-transition corrosion rates, the interface had a disordered structure, and pores were found in the oxide very close to the interface.

evidence_span: In Zircaloy-4 with short annealing times and high post-transition corrosion rates, the interface had a disordered structure, and pores were found in the oxide very close to the interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: In Zircaloy-4 with low uniform corrosion rates, the interface consisted of highly ordered, columnar grains.
